La Sra Nelida es comerciante, tiene 53años, esta casada con el sr Leonor quien es Contratista de Obras,  juntos tienen 5 hijos. La señora Comenta que se dedica a la venta de prendas de todo tipo, en lo cual le va muy bien por que ya tiene una clientela bien definida.
Ella solicita el crédito para la comprar prendas de verano, lo cual la ayudara a abastecerse y cumplir con sus clientes. Su meta es poner un local de ventas de verduras y frutas en un lugar estrategico.
texts.en:
This committee was organzied by Sra. Nelida.  She was a member of another group before, but had to leave it for personal reasons.  She decided to organize a new committee and invite her friends and neighbors to join so that they could move forward together.  The new group is called La Primavera.
Sra. Nelida, 53, owns a commerical business.  She and her husband, Sr. Leonor, a construction worker, have 5 children.  She says that she sells clothing of all kinds and that she's successful because she her customers come back to her again and again.   
Sra. Nelida is applying for a loan to buy merchandise appropriate for summer.  The loan will allow her to stock her business and meet future demand from her customers.  Her goal is to open a fruit and vegetable sales business in a high-traffic zone.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for her retail clothing business.

loans.name: Flor María

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita en Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar conocimos a la  señora Flor. Tiene 48 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación  tiene  4 hijos ya todos mayores de edad dos de ellos viven con ella. El marido es agricultor.

Ella es una gran  ama de casa que hace varios años adecuo en su casa un local donde puso una pequeña tienda donde vende productos de primera necesidad, allí sus clientes pueden encontrar granos, aceite, detergentes, legumbres, frutas, pollo, pescado, carne y queso por libras y en cantidades más pequeñas al gusto de sus clientes. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 19h00. Lleva más de 10 años con su negocio y le va muy bien.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar arroz, azúcar, detergentes, embutidos, carne, legumbres, entre otros productos. Lleva 12 ciclos en el Banco Comunal y le gusta porque gracias a los créditos ha podido mejorar cada dia mas su negocio.
 
Su sueño es tener una tienda más grande.
texts.en:
The communal bank María Auxiliadora meets in the parish of Sequita in prosperous Montecristi in the canton of Manabita and they are hard working people proud of their roots. La Sequita is a parish where the people are honest and only know how to work and care for their families.

Here we meet Flor who is 48 years old, married and from this relationship she has four children, all of them adults, with two of them still living with her. Her husband is a farmer.

She is a housewife who some years ago made an appropriate place in her home where she put a little store where she sells staples, and there her customers can find grains, oil, detergents, vegetables, fruits, chickens, fish, meat and cheese by the pound and in smaller quantities if her customers prefer. She works every day from 6:00AM until 7:00PM. She has had more than ten years in her business and things are going very well.

She will use the money from this loan to buy rice, sugar, detergents, sausages, meats, vegetables, and other products. She has been with the community bank through twelve cycles and she likes it because thanks to the loans she has been able to improve her daily business.

Her dream is to have a larger store.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, detergents, sausages, meats, vegetables, and other products

loans.name: Suma Uru Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “SUMA URU” iniciará su primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del centro focal Los Andes, está compuesta por nueve integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Basilia es la tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: costura de deportivos, venta de parrillas, comerciante de marial escolar, costura y venta de busos, venta de celulares, confección de ropa, confección de mantas, tienda de barrio.

La señora Basilia, indica que hace cinco años que trabaja en Pro Mujer y que integro la institución por invitación de una amiga. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de parrillas que viene trabajando hace años, aprendiendo el mismo de sus padres.

El crédito que ahora sacará es para aumentar su capital (compra de fierros) que adquirirá de las ferreterias, por mayor, y posterior a la elaboración lo comercializará en su puesto de venta. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar a su familia, pues ella vive en  y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el ahorro.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Suma Uru" will start its first loan cycle with Pro Mujer, at the Los Andes central office.  This group has 9 members and is led by a board of directors where Basilia is the Treasurer.  The members of this communal bank have a variety of businesses, including: making sports clothes, selling grills, selling school supplies, making and selling sweatshirts, selling cellular phones, making clothing, making blankets, and a grocery store.

Basilia states that she has been working with Pro Mujer for 5 years, and that she joined the institution at the invitation of a friend.  Now she has a business selling grills that she has been working in for years.  She learned this trade from her parents.

The loan that she is going to take will be used to increase her capital, by purchasing iron from the ironmonger's at wholesale.  She will use this iron to make the grills that she sells from her stand.  This type of work allows her to generate resources to support her family.  She has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answered that she enjoys being able to save.

loans.use: to buy iron to make grills

loans.name: Mirvat

texts.en:
Mirvat, a 40 year old Palestinian woman, lives and works in a camp for Palestinian refugees located in North Lebanon. 
She is divorced and raising her five children by herself, which requires a stable source of income. That is why she decided to open her clothes shop for kids and women two years ago. However, she has 12 years of experience in selling clothes as she used to be an employee in one of the main clothes shop in the camp. Mirvat also fixes clothes during her free time for extra revenue. Her two daughters help her in the housing expenses, they are employees in a company outside the camp. 
Before the winter season, Mirvat is asking for a 3,597,000 Lebanese pounds loan for the first time from Kiva partner Ibdaa in order to buy large quantities of clothes at a lower price. 
Mirvat doesn't have a lot of competitors in the area, she is friendly with her clients and is very devoted to her shop. Her brother helped her to open the shop in 2013 in an excellent location of the camp and she has been relying on herself since then.

loans.use: to buy winter clothes for her shop

loans.name: Célestine

texts.en:
This is a group loan request submitted by the ten members of the women’s tontine Takusaan de Ayidjidjo, represented by Célestine D..  Here is a translation of their microenterprise proposal:  “This is a project of small-scale trade in local products of the département of Oussouye (lemon juice, palm oil and dried fish).  These products, which are very abundant within the département, will be purchased and resold in areas where they are in short supply – in other words, the exchange of products between regions.  These products, which are in high demand and very nutritious, have motivated us to present this proposal for financing, after a study of the market and previous attempts at these activities with very limited financial resources.  The objective of the loan is to:
  • Reduce the problem of rural migration
  • Create employment for women
  • Help to improve and diversify the local diet and to ensure self-sufficiency in food

  The activities of the enterprise are: the sale of local products (lemon juice, palm oil, dried fish).  These products will be purchased in Oussouye and resold in areas where they are lacking such as Kolda, Tamba, Kaolack, and Dakar; by ship or by highway.  We are sure of being able to repay the entire loan without any difficulty and thereby remaining eligible for additional financing.  

To start the business:

Lemon juice:    350 F * 150 l *3 =      157500 F

Palm oil:           1000 F * 120 l * 2 =   240000 F

Dried fish:        500 F * 150 kg * 2 =  150000 F

Forestry taxes                                     50000 F

Total:                                                  700000 F”  

Background

Senegal is one of the world’s poorest countries, yet its solid democratic tradition and highly developed associational life distinguish it from other countries in its income group.  Especially remarkable are Senegal’s networks of rotating savings and credit associations, known as tontines.  Commonly organized by groups of twenty to thirty housewives who live in the same village, the tontines provide poor women throughout the country with small loans to finance modest income-generating activities.  Repayment rates within these associations are excellent, because they are based on local reputation and personal trust between the members.  However, their financial resources are limited to the contributions of their members, frequently subsistence farmers with very little disposable income.  This has prevented the traditional tontines from meeting the demand for rural microenterprise loans and restricted their impact on the economic development of their communities.  Senegal Ecovillage Microfinance (SEM) works with our partner organization CRESP to bridge this gap by linking traditional village credit associations with outside sources of finance.

loans.use: Purchase of local products - lemon juice, palm oil and dried fish - and transport to other regional markets for resale

loans.name: Bibi

texts.en:
6 years ago Bibi decided to buy plot of land and to become a wine-grower. She now has a vineyard. 
This 57-year-old woman likes her business. She irrigates and cultivates the plot of land.
Bibi lives with her 6 children in Yenikand village,Salyan region,Azerbaijan.
She requires a loan of $600 with which she plans to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta is one of SPBD’s new members from the village of Faleula. Her idea was to start a small business making and selling sandwiches. Her customers include people in the village and the village school. Elisapeta is trying her best to make her business successful so that she can support her two children, whose father passed away two years ago.

loans.use: Purchase of eggs, canned spaghetti, tuna, bread, butter, mayonnaise

loans.name: Foday

texts.en: Foday B. is married with six children.  He runs a small business in his house in Makeni town of Sierra Leone.  A hard-working man, Foday expanded his business with his first loan from SMT. Foday is requesting a new loan to diversify the business to include rice and other local agriculture products.  This will earn more income for the family to meet household expenses such education expenses, medicines, etc.

loans.use: Expand inventory of shop to include rice and local agriculture products

loans.name: Hilda

texts.en:
Hilda Rossana P. T. is 25 years old and has a 2-year old daughter. She has a small store located in her house where she sells stationery, notebooks and cosmetics. She just started her business a year ago. This is her first business and it has been a huge success. She decided to start her business in order stay at home because she did not want to leave her house to work. With her store, she is able to stay at home and take care of her daughter at the same time.

Her husband works long hours in a factory and Hilda usually gives part of her loan to him so he can buy equipment for his job. Without her previous loan, Hilda would not have been able to successfully run her store and support her family because her daughter was sick for a while which caused her to incur more expenses. She reinvests the income she earns each week in her business. Thus, the previous loans she recevied gave more capital to work with and she was able to survive a tough time in her life.

She purchases her merchandise from San Lorenzo and Mercado 4, a market that sells very cheaply-priced products. She travels on an hour-long bus ride to purchase her merchandise. She is hoping to receive another loan to buy more stationery, especially notebooks since the school year has started again after its winter vacation.

loans.use: Buy notebooks.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita is 36 years old and fights daily to help increase the family income so her children may have all that is necessary to have a good life. Her perseverance has given her family the assurance that she does everything possible to make their lives pleasant.

Thanks to the hard work she invests in agriculture, she was able to purchase a small plot of land that her husband is farming. Margarita also has a small vegetable garden in her house that her children help her with. However, the produce has decreased and the family expenses are using up the little capital they have. In turn, this has reduced the amount of money available for purchasing seeeds and fertilizers for the new plot of land they have invested in.

Margarita and her husband have decided to purchase potato seeds as this crop is needed by the community year round. The situation which Margarita finds herself in has made her ask for help, with the hope that she will find sensitive and caritative collaborators to help her get through these hard times.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.

Margarita tiene 36 años de edad y lucha día a día por convertirse en un importante apoyo para su esposo con el optimismo de mejorar los ingresos de su hogar y mantener sin privaciones a sus hijos, su perseverancia hace que su familia mantenga entera confianza en ella y en su desempeño diario.Gracias al esmero que pone en su actividad agrícola pudo adquirir un terrenito en el que ahora labora su esposo y establecer una chacrita pequeña en su hogar en el que trabaja con el apoyo de sus hijos y ahora se han convertido en sus mejores socios.Sin embargo sus ingresos han disminuido notablemente y ya no solventan los gastos de su familia ni le permite comprar la misma cantidad de semillas, abonos y fertilizantes que hacen falta para hacer trabajar adecuadamente su nuevo terreno en el que ha decidido sembrar papa para mejorar su situación ya que este tubérculo es requerido todo el año por las familias de su localidad y el público en general.Este hecho por el que atraviesa la llevó a hacer pública su situación con la esperanza de encontrar a personas caritativas colaboradoras y sensibles a fin de que puedan dar respuesta a su petición en corto tiempo.

loans.use: Purchase potato seeds

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en:
Mercedes and her partner have three children together - two girls, fifteen and ten, and a boy, eight.  She bakes empanadas and prepares freshly squeezed juice for sale in her community.  Before school each morning, Mercedes’ children help her prepare the goods for sale that day.

Mercedes walks through the neighborhood, carting her empanadas and fresh juice.  Her customers vary daily, but the workingmen in the neighborhood regularly enjoy the freshly baked snacks and juice.  Mercedes plans on buying more fruit and other baking ingredients with her loan.  She explains that, with some good fortune, her business has plenty of growth potential.  Someday, Mercedes dreams of opening a buffet style luncheonette, where she can serve twenty to twenty five customers.

loans.use: Purchase of Baking Ingredients and Fruits for Empanada and Juice Sales

loans.name: Jowfma's Group

texts.en:
Jowfma N. is a 47 year old mother of 5 children (30, 25, 18, 11, 5) who currently operates a restaurant. She wants this loan to open a retail shop. With the profits she hopes to purchase a commercial motorcycle for rent (a “boda-boda”).

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To open a retail shop

loans.name: Arshan's Group

texts.en:
My name is Arshan B. and I have lived in Pakpattan, a small town in Pakistan, for my entire life. I am a widow and mother of four: two boys and two girls. My brother lives with me and supports us. We are applying for this loan so that he can buy a rickshaw.

There are several other women in my loan group: Shama B. will use this loan to buy more items to sell from her fruit cart, Khursheed B., who supports her family by making traditional hair ornaments known as Paranda, has applied for this loan to buy fertilizer for her husband's farm. Allah M. will use the loan to buy a rickshaw.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw and other items for several small businesses

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. has been a trader for the past four years. Her husband repairs freezers and air conditioners around Cape Coast. They have three children.

Mary is requesting $275 to expand her current stock of products.

Mary is also a member of a lending group called “Wisdom Group”, which consists of 14 members in Cape Coast, Ghana.

loans.use: To expand her current stock of products.

loans.name: Erika Massiel

texts.es:
Ericka M. is a young woman of 24 years, she lives in the Spring neighborhood, she is married, her husband works in a big private business. To help with the expenses, for the last 3 years she has dedicated herself to the sale of cosmetics, a business that she began with a loan that her mother gave her, with her quality and commercial activity she has maintained a clientele and has acquired others through recommendations, she has future plans to open a small store of various feminine products and to have children that will make her life even happier. She requests a loan to purchase beauty products so that she can sell them before people start taking their vacations at the beach, this time is important for her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Ericka M. es una joven de 24 años de edad, vive en el Barrio la Primavera, casada, su esposo trabaja como bodeguero en una empresa privada grande del país. Para apoyar en los gastos, desde hace 3 años se ha dedicado a la venta de cosméticos, negocio que inició con un préstamo que su madre le hizo, con su calidez y actividad comercial ha mantenido su clientela y captado por recomendación otras, de esta manera dentro de sus planes futuros esta abrir una tiendita de variedad de productos femeninos y tener pronto hijos que alegren aún mas su vida. Solicita un préstamo para comprar productos de belleza e irlos a vender antes que empiecen las vacaciones de playa, esta época es importante para sus ventas, en donde tiene pedidos que cumplir.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products.

loans.name: Paula

texts.es:
Paula works selling cosmetics. She started in the field 2 years ago helping a friend. Later, she bought the catalogs and began to sell on her own amongst family members and neighbors. She needed the extra income to help her husband with the household expenses.

She is requesting a loan for $250, which she will use to buy merchandise. She will repay the loan in 3 months. With your help Paula will be able to move herself ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Paula se dedica la venta de cosméticos, empezó hace 2 años ayudando a una amiga después Ella compro los catálogos y empezó a vender por su cuenta entre familiares y vecinos. Emprendió esta actividad ya que necesitaba de un ingreso extra para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de la casa.

Ahora solicita un crédito por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancía. Con tu apoyo Paula saldrá adelante.

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina has a small business in Melitopol, Ukraine. She sells a variety of children’s clothing from a little outdoor kiosk at the central market in Melitopol. Galina has had her business for over ten years. When she was first starting out she chose to sell a product that was a good fit for her. Divorced and living by herself, Galina would like to continue developing her business so she can improve her standard of living. She currently makes about $320 per month.

Galina has requested a loan to purchase new summer clothing inventory. She should have good sales and resulting good income during the warm summer months.

loans.use: Purchase summer clothing inventory

loans.name: Cosme

texts.es:
Cosme is married to Mrs. Judith Martínez Suárez, who is a homemaker. They have 3 sons: Juan Cosme (38, married); Ever Javier (29, married); Eduarudo Isaac Elisa (27, lives and works outside of the city).

He started his business after having worked for several companies under a fixed contract, but never receiving seniority. He was also a self-employed public transportation driver, so he never had the chance to retire nor earn a pension, which motivated him to start his own business to get ahead.

He started in February of 2006 when he asked his wife to order some silver jewelry from her provider because at that time, she was the one who sold jewelry. He then started to sell jewelry to his fellow taxi cab drivers because his one of his sons owns a taxi cab and sometimes lets him borrow it in the evenings so that he can make extra money. That is when he seizes the opportunity to sell silver jewelry and watches to his co-workers. He has been prosperous in this business so far.

He needs a loan of $300.00 USD, which he will repay in 3 months, so that he can purchase more jewelry and watches, offering a greater selection of merchandise to his customers and increasing both his sales and profits.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Cosme está casado con la Sra. Judith Martínez Suárez, quien se dedica a las labores del hogar. Tienen 3 hijos: Juan Cosme de 38 años, casado; Ever Javier de 29 años, casado y Eduardo Isaac Elisa de 27 años, el vive y trabaja fuera de la ciudad.

Inició el negocio despues de trabajar en varias empresas, en todas ellas por contrato fijo y nunca hizo antigüedad, además de que fei chofer de transporte público por su cuenta, por lo que no tuvo la posibilidad de jubilarse o pensionarse, esto lo motivo a iniciar su propio negocio para salir adelante.

Comenzó en Febrero de 2006, cuando le pidio a su esposa que le encargara con su proveedor un lote de joyería de plata, ya que en ese entonces ella era la que vendía joyería, lo cual hizo y empezo a venderla entre sus compañeros taxistas, ya que tiene un hijo que es propietario de un taxi y a veces se lo presta por la tarde para que obtenga un ingreso, y es ahí cuando aprovecha para yvenderla a sus compañeros los artículos de plata y relojes y desde entonces le ha ido bien.

El necesita un prestamo por US $300 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar más joyería y relojes y tener una mejor variedad de artículos que ofrecer a sus clientes y asi incrementar sus ventas y ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise (jewelry and watches)

loans.name: Faïda (Elegance). Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Faïda group are on average 38 years old with four children. They live in traditional families with their husbands, children and co-wives in the Sogomougou area of Koutiala (the Sikasso region of the Republic of Mali). Linked by being neighbors, relatives and colleagues, this group generally trades in fruits, vegetables, tubers and clothing. Because they have confidence in each other, they decided to enter the Soro Yiriwaso micro-credit program, through which they just received their first group loan (solidarity loan).

They generally get their supplies from neighboring villages or from sellers of fruits, vegetables and tubers on market days. Their clothing supply comes from Bamako or Burkina Faso (a neighboring country). They usually buy fruit by the sack which they stock and resell at retail prices at the Koutiala market.

With this loan, the Faïda group estimates that each member will make 40,000 CFA francs in profit, which will be used to pay the interest on the loan, help with increasing family expenses, and contribute to their savings. In the future, the Faïda group plans to enter the wholesale fruit and vegetable business and gain a national reputation.

Translated from French by Pamela Poole, Kiva volunteer.

Les membres du groupe faïda, ont une moyenne d’age de 38 ans 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris, enfants et coépouses dans le quartier Sogomougou de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso République du Mali). Liées par des liens de voisinages de parentés et professionnels, elles exercent généralement le commerce de fruits, légumes, de tubercules et d’ habits. Se faisant mutuellement confiance les membres du groupe ont décidé ensemble d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso auprès de laquelle institution de microfinance elles viennent de bénéficier de leur premier pret de groupe (prêt solidaire).

Elles s’approvisionnent généralement. dans les villages voisins ou les jours de foire auprès des paysans spécialisés dans la production de fruits, légumes et tubercules. Par contre les habits sont achétés à Bamako ou au Burkina Fasso (Pays voisin du Mali). Elles achètent généralement les fruits par sac qui sont stockés et revendus en détail au marché de Koutiala.

Les femmes du groupe faïda comptent chacune réaliser, avec ce prêt; 40 000 CFA. de bénéfice qui servira à payer les intérêts du prêt, subvenir aux charges de famille de plus en plus importantes et renforcer leurs fonds propres. Dans l’avenir, le groupe faïda compte devenir des grossistes en fruits et légumes avec une réputation nationale.

loans.use: To buy pagnes (traditional wraparound clothing item) and sacks of tubers (root vegetables)

loans.name: Rufina

texts.es:
Rufina is 36 years old, separated from her husband eight years ago, and a mother of two young daughters. She was only able to study through primary school. She presently lives on Ave. Niños.

She is a member of the Community Bank Julia Jiménez of the Santa Rosa District, Providence of Collao. With the first loan of 300 Soles, she bought three sheep to sell as meat, which increased her capital and now she has a grocery store.

With this loan of 2000 Soles, which she will repay in four months, she will buy three bags of sweets, five packs of soda, five bags of noodles, and other items for her store that are sold daily. She will also buy vegetables: one sack of carrots, one box of tomatoes, 25 pounds of onions, two bunches of gourds, etc. for selling at the Saturday market in Mazocruz.

Rufina says that since she joined the Community Bank, her business has increased and she is very happy.

Her dream is to continue increasing her capital for her business in order to be able to obtain more earnings and educate her daughters until they become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

Rufina tiene 36 años de edad, es separada hace 08 años, madre de dos hijas menores de edad, ella solo pudo estudiar primaria completa, actualmente vive en la Av. Niños s/n.

Es socia del Banco Comunal Julia Jiménez del Distrito de Santa Rosa, Provincia del Collao con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compró 03 ovejas para vender en carne, fue incrementando su capital ahora tiene su tienda de abarrotes.

Con este préstamo de S/. 2,000.00 Nuevos Soles, que pagará en 04 meses, comprará 03 bolsas de golosinas, 05 paquetes de gaseosas 05 bolsas de fideos y otros para su tienda que vende diariamente, a su vez comprará verduras: 01 saco de zanahoria, 01 caja de tomate, 01 arroba de cebolla, 02 cabezas de zapallo, etc. para vender en la feria sabatina en Mazocruz.

Rufina, indica que desde que integra el Banco Comunal, incrementó su negocio, ella está muy contenta.

Su sueño es seguir aumentando más capital a su negocio para así poder obtener más ganancias y educar a sus hijas hasta que sean profesionales.

loans.use: Buy various products (groceries).

loans.name: Bayi

texts.fr:
Madame A. Bayi est née le 31 décembre 1955 à Lomé. Elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle a pour activité la vente des sacs d’écoliers et de sacs de voyage à côté d’une grande station d’essence de son quartier.
Elle a commencé cette activité depuis 2002 et à une expérience qui lui permet de bien vendre malgré la concurrence.
A l’approche de cette rentrée scolaire, elle sollicite ce premier crédit pour acheter 120 sacs d’écoliers et 40 sacs de voyage.
texts.en:
Mrs. Bayi A. was born on December 31, 1955 in Lomé. She is married and is the mother of 4 children. Her business entails selling school bags and travelling bags beside a big petrol station in her neighborhood.

She began this business in 2002 and has enough experience to allow her to make a lot of sales in spite of the competition.

As the school year begins, she is requesting this first loan to buy 120 school bags and 40 travelling bags.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of travelling bags and school bags

loans.name: Lola

texts.es: Lola (38 años) tiene dificultades en su economía, ya que ha tenido 8 hijos, de los cuales 6 estudian, ella y su esposo tienen que trabajar donde se les presente la oportunidad de ganar algo de dinero.  Madruga para preparar el desayuno de sus hijos, asimismo tiene que cocinar el almuerzo temprano, para ir a la chacra con su esposo, no solo se dedican a su propia chacra; sino también, trabajan como jornales para los cultivos de otras personas.  Siembran granadillas y café, pero esta vez quieren incursionar en la siembra de caigua, por que demora solo 4 meses en  producir, y les deja una buena ganancia, sobre todo en tiempo de verano, a ella le agrada mucho el negocio, cuando ya no está en la chacra, lleva sus productos a los mercados, mientras tanto, su esposo (en la foto nos muestra una caja de cerveza) se queda en casa vendiendo gaseosas, algunos bocaditos y  cervezas, lo más dificultoso para ellos es la falta de capital, pero igual no pierden las esperanzas de mejorar su casa y poder tener una bodega con el tiempo.  Lola y su esposo trabajan tanto en la chacra o en otra actividad que se presente, con la finalidad de educarlos a sus 6 hijos en etapa escolar.  Con el dinero del préstamo, invertirán en la  siembra de caigua porque justamente saldría para la época del verano, donde su precio es muy bueno.
texts.en:
Lola, who is 38 years old, is having difficult times economically. Six of her eight children are in school, and she and her husband have to work where there are opportunities to make some money. She gets up very early to make breakfast for her kids and also makes lunch before she heads off to her farmland with her husband. She doesn't work exclusively on her own land, but also also works as a day laborer on other people's crops. She cultivates passion fruit and coffee, but this time she also wants to include caigua, a regional plant that will take only four months to produce with high margins, especially in the summer. Lola is very pleased with her business. When she isn't in the fields, she takes her products to the local markets. Meanwhile her husband (holding the box of beer in the photo) stays at home selling soft drinks, sandwiches and beer. The most difficult thing for them is a lack of capital, but they have not lost hope of improving their home and, with time, opening up a bodega. Lola and her husband work so hard on their fields and their other activities with the goal of providing for their six children who are still in school. With the loan, they will invest in the cultivation of caigua because summertime will soon come when their prices will be very good.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her land to cultivate caigua, a regional plant

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mrs. Asha M. resident of Tangal lives in a nuclear family with her husband and one child. Her husband's name is Shyam M. and he is a house painter. Her daughter is studying in grade 1.

Mrs. M.'s family's living conditions are miserable as her husband’s work is not permanent. Sometimes he may not get a job for a month. So they can hardly fulfill their basic needs. They can’t send their child to boarding school.

So to over come this problem, Mrs. M. decided to open a momo (meat dumplings) shop. But due to lack of money, she is unable to open her shop. So Mrs. M. is requesting her first loan of Rs 10000.00 to open the momo shop.

loans.use: To open a meat dumplings shop

loans.name: Vann

texts.en:
Mrs. Vann M. lives in Tie Buon village in Kampong Chhnang province.  She is a pig breeder.  Her husband, Mr. Sok Nim, is a bamboo seller. 

Even though they have different businesses, they still earn less income than is needed to support their household, so they want to expand their businesses.  Thus, Mrs. Vann M. decided to ask for a loan to purchase more bamboo, piglets, and pig food for her business.  She hopes to increase her income and provide a better life for her family. 

She is 38 years old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending the local school, while the others are too young to work or study because they are at the ages of one month and two years old.

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo, piglets, and pig food for her business.

loans.name: Suega

texts.en: Suega P., 49, is married with 8 children.  She has many years of experience in the vegetable garden business. She sells to the village and general public 4 days per week. She has  previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 150 Tala (~62 USD).  SPBD loans are Suega’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. The loan will be used to purchase chemicals, seedlings and equipment used in gardening.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, seedlings, and bush knives

loans.name: Zehar Batool M. Aslam Pervaiz Group

texts.en:
Zehar Batool baji is a 46-year-old married lady and has resided in a city called Borewala, Pakistan for the past 45 years. Her parents couldn’t provide her with an education, and she left school after completing 8th standard. Her husband's name is M. A. P. and he has a rice-selling business. He buys the sacks of rice from different cities (Lahore, Kasur) and sells in different shops in Borewala. He has 20 years of experience in this business.

Zehar baji is the mother of six kids: four daughters and two sons. All of her kids are getting an education from a local school near their house. Zehar baji herself is involved in making decorative pieces. She makes wooden pieces with writing on them: various Holy names, e.g., “Allah and Muhammad”. Her art is very famous in her community and outside of the community as well. She successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a micro-finance institute in Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more wooden sticks to expand her decorative pieces business.

She is the group leader for some more women frpm her locality. Parveen Akhtar baji wants a loan to buy bicycles to re-sell. Faizan baji wants a loan to buy wires and switch boards for her electric items business. Majidan baji wants a loan to buy groceries for her grocery shop. Shaheen baji wants a loan to buy medicines for her medical store.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy wooden sticks to make decorative pieces to sell

loans.name: Peter Rey

texts.en:
Peter Rey L., who is 40 years old with two children, owns a small parcel of land to plant rice. His wife, Rita L., is very supportive of Peter's business efforts. Aside from farming, Peter earns income from driving a 'Sikad,' also known as passenger tricycle. This is a popular form of transportation in the Philippines. For 13 years, he has been farming and driving a 'Sikad'. 

He is asking a loan of Php 10,00 from CEVI. He will use the loan purchase four sacks of rice seeds, two sacks of Urea fertilizers and other farm inputs. His loan will help him obtain the maximum yield from his farm. 

CEVI supports Peter to sustain his businesses. He is provided with credit assistance, training and insurance coverage by joining the CEVI credit program.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is married. She is an entrepreneur from Vinogradovo where she sells children’s clothing in the central city market. She launched this business 5 years ago. One of the important factors of its growth has been financial assistance she received from Nadiya Ukraine. Presently, she has 15,000 Grivnas in gross income. Her monthly profit is about 4,000 Grivnas.

Marina is hoping to continue growing her business. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 Grivnas to expand her vending capacity. She believes additional funding will help her keep a stable position in the market in this time of crisis and ensure consistent development of her trade. One of Marina’s long-term goals is opening a new vending facility.

loans.use: To expand her vending business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty H. is a 42-year-old woman. She is widowed and the mother of four children. All of her children are currently in school. She lives with the children in Eguase in the central region of Ghana.

She is a food vendor who sells fante kenkey by the roadside in her neighborhood. Fante kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and eaten with hot pepper and fried fish. It can also be mashed for iced kenkey or kenkey porridge. She has added the sale of sweet potatoes to her inventory.

She has been in this business for ten years. She has many customers because many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey for breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials, such as maize, meat, fish, vegetables, sweet potatoes and firewood. She would appreciate your support. She belongs to the village bank called Awake.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Abra E. est propriétaire d’une baraque installée au bord de la route à Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Âgée de 40 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. son activité consiste à acquérir des marchandises au près des grossistes et de venir les étaler dans sa baraque. Elle désire avec ce crédit renforcer son commerce en aménageant sa baraque et l’approvisionner. Elle est à son deuxième crédit et le premier a été remboursé promptement
texts.en:
Abra E. is the owner of a stall situated along side the road to Lomé, the capital of Togo. She is 40 years old, married, and the mother of three. Her business involves acquiring merchandise from wholesalers and displaying it in her stall. She would like to use this loan to bolster her business by fixing up her stall and stocking it. She is on her second loan, and the first one was promptly repaid.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To fix up her stall and to stock it

loans.name: Mariama Kesso

texts.fr: Mariama Kesso, 51 ans est mariée avec 04 enfants  en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Sinthiang Coundara depuis 6 ans. Mariama achète des arachides pour les  transformer en pâte d’arachide et vendre. Elle veut renforcer son commerce pour soutenir son mari dans les charges familiales
texts.en:
Mariama Kesso, 51, is married and raising four children. She has been a member of the village bank of Sinthiang Coundara for 6 years. Mariama buys peanuts to transform into peanut butter which she sells. She wants to bolster her little business so as to help her husband support their family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Production and sale of peanut butter

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena G. is married with two daughters. She sells headgear in the central market of Novomoskovsk. A wide assortment of the latest items attracts many customers to her vending location. She has enjoyed stable sales for the past ten years. Currently, her profit is approximately $465 a month. 

Yelena is hoping to continue developing her business and providing for her family. She is planning to use the loan to purchase additional merchandise and to expand the assortment of inventory for sale. She loves working with this type of merchandise and is ready to put more effort into its further growth and expansion.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Sa Beoun

texts.en: M. Sa Beoun, 38, is a worker whose job is splitting stone into pieces for construction buildings and infrastructure. She and her husband can earn $3 per day. She and her husband have three children. One of her children is a student and the rest are working, like their parents. She wants to take a $500 loan from KIVA. This loan would be used to buy a type of equipment that will enable her family members to split the stone faster and more easily into pieces to sell and make a good income. This loan will allow the family to generate more income.

loans.use: To buy stone-splitting equipment.

loans.name: Fatama Group

texts.en:
Fatama is the group leader of Fatama group. There are three members in this group and they are requesting a group loan of 20,000 Afghani to expand their businesses.

Fatama wants to take a loan for her son who has a clothes shop.

Gulsoam wants to take a loan for her husband who is a trader.

Nagia wants to take a loan for her husband who has a fruit and vegetables shop.

So they are very thankful to AFS and to Kiva lenders who are able to support the whole world.

loans.use: To expand her son's business

loans.name: Sharifan Rafiq Group

texts.en:
Sharifan baji, wife of R., has been a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan, for the past fifteen years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband runs a scrap business in the community. He trades in different used items such as cupboards, iron doors and windows. He has been doing this work for over five years.

Sharifan baji is a very caring and supportive lady and performs her duties efficiently. Her family is very happy with her because of her calm nature. She is applying for a loan to buy scrap to advance her husband’s scrap business. Sharifan baji is seated on the left in the photo.

This loan group consists of two additional people:

Zareena baji and Shahnaz baji each want a loan to buy timber to sell.

loans.use: To buy scrap for her husband's scrap business

loans.name: Antony Obwana

texts.en:
Antony J. is a 41-year-old married father of three children. His business is located at Baharini centre in Eldoret Town and his main clients are residents of Baharini.

He has been in the cereal business for the past six years and his business has been doing very well. 

He was introduced to KADET by a group member. He intends to restock his cereal and vegetable shop with the loan he is taking. 

In the future, he intends to expand his business to be a wholesale shop, and also be able to get good income which will enable him to diversify to a bigger shop and be able to provide a good education for his children.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To add stock for his cereal and vegetabes shop

loans.name: Ilhom

texts.en:
S. Ilhom is a talented entrepreneur with a successful business selling teenagers' footwear in the market. He is married with two children. Ilhom started his business 10 years ago out of a desire to earn a living and meet people's clothing needs. He sells footwear that are both popular and affordable, which helps to ensure a strong demand for his products. Ilhom is a serious business-owner who wants his business to be the best it can be while continuing to grow and be profitable.

Ilhom has requested a loan of $1050 to purchase new inventory. The change of seasons makes this a busy time of year for business-owners like Ilhom. This loan will help him keep a good supply of inventory on hand so he can meet customer demand and make a good profit.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new footwear to sell.

loans.name: Puerta Del Sol Group

texts.es:
Barbara S. de 75 años hace 10 años aproximadamente trabaja con la familia de Pro Mujer, cuenta que  para acceder al préstamo tubo que capacitarse tres meses, al inicio eran pocos, pero poco a poco las mujeres se fueron agrupando (vecinas y amigas), en las capacitaciones les orientaban en como administrar su negocio. Actualmente pertenece al grupo “Puera del Sol” que a su vez es parte del Centro Focal “Alto Lima”.
Barbara tiene 6 hijos, todos casados y dos de ellos aprendieron del negocio que ella maneja, que es la elaboración de pitas o sogas.
Las demás integrantes tambien tienen sus propios negocios, algunas se dedican a la producción de mantas y chompas, otras de dedican a la comercialización de productos tales como ropa de bebe, mochilas, abarrotes. Todas necesitan del préstamo para adquirir materia prima y mercadería.
texts.en:
Barbara S. is 75 years old and for approximately 10 years has been working with the Pro Mujer family. She notes that in order to access the loan she had to train for three months. At the beginning, there were only a few of them, but gradually women began to form groups (neighbors and friends). In the training, they were taught how to manage their businesses. Currently, she belongs to the "Puerta del Sol" group which in turn is part of the "Alto Lima" Centro Focal. Barbara has six children, all of whom are married and two of whom learned the business that she manages, which is making string or rope. The other members also have their own businesses. Some are dedicated to the production of blankets and sweaters while others are dedicated to selling products such as baby clothes, backpacks, and groceries. All need a loan to acquire basic materials and merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Divjak, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and basic materials.

loans.name: Petrona Del Carmen

texts.es:
la sra. PETRONA DEL CARMEN L. se dedica a la elaboracion de pan casero, actividad que realiza en su casa de habitación con ayuda de sus hijas, su producto lo distribuye en diferentes negocios de la zona
con los ingresos que le genera cubre los gastos en el hogar en un 100%  tiene tres hijas a su cargo que cursan sus estudios secundarios en centros educativos de la localidad , este credito que esta solicitando le va a ser de gran apoyo ya que necesita comprar materia prima al por mayor lo que le permite bajar los costos para elaborar su producto y asi obteniendo una mayor rentabilidad en su negocio.  
nos comento que uno de los factores que le permite producir buen producto es la selección  de materias primas de calidad lo que le ha permitido mantener una excelente clientela generandole asi mejores ventas y obtener utilidades que le facilitan cumplir con sus obligaciones.

loans.use: compra de maiz, manteca, harina, huevos, dulce, margarina, azucar, queso, leña

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 34 years old and she is married with 4 children.She sells groceries to earn a living and also to satisfy the needs of her family.She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. she says thanks to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Fatys

texts.es:
La Sra.Fatys, alquila un ambiente para la venta de almuerzo familiar, entre los platos que ofrece a diario son: Sopa de maní, Picante de Pollo, bife y los fines de semana platos especiales como el Pescado frito, pescado al Horno, Majadito de pato (plato tipico de Santa Cruz) y otros. También cuenta con la venta de gaseosas, asi como la preparación de refrescos para la venta como el de Mocochinchi (durazno seco)y la Limonada. Cuenta con el apoyo de sus dos hijos para la atención de la pensión. La mayor competencia  que tiene son los dos días de feria (martes y sábados) que se realiza a dos cuadras de la pensión. 
La señora emprendió este negocio hace dos años atrás cuando la situación económica de su familia se ponía difícil, había tomado la decisión de viajar a otro país para mejorar su situación económica, como lo hicieron muchos, pero significaría la desintegración de su  familia y decidió quedarse y trabajar atendiendo una pensión, contando con el apoyo de su familia y la de su hermana quien le ofreció la tienda, actualmente ahora ella alquila la tienda porque ya cuenta con ingresos para cubrir el alquiler como las necesidades de su familia.
El sueño que tiene la señora al margen de mejorar su negocio ofertar nuevos platos ya que la tienda se encuentra en una muy buena ubicación
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatys rents a stall and sells home-styled lunches, amongst the dishes that she serves daily include: peanut soup, spicy chicken, and steak. In the weekends she serves special plates like fried fish, baked fish, duck majadito (a mixture of beef jerky and rice served with a fried egg and a banana—typical dish of Santa Cruz), and others. She also sells sodas and prepares drinks like (dried peaches) and lemonade. She has the help of her two children to take care of her lodgings. Most of the competition that she has is in the two days of the street market (Tuesdays and Saturdays) that are two blocks from her pension.

Mrs. Fatys began this business two years ago when her family’s economic situation was getting complicated. She wanted to travel to another country to better her economic wellbeing like many others have done, but that would separate the family and decided to stay and work. She takes care of a pension with the help of her family and of her sister who offered her the store that she now rents because she has the income to take care of the rent as well as the necessities of her family.

Mrs. Fatys’ dream is to improve her business by providing new dishes since the store is very well located.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in fixed assets.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
María tiene 43 años, está casada y madre de 3 hijos, con quienes viven es su casa propia.
Ella tiene una bodega, por lo que se siente muy orgullosa de su trabajo, ya que su madre le enseñó sobre este negocio sin tener que recurrir al trabajo de campo, actividad que no le gusta realizar. Es así que a las 5:30 de la mañana abre su establecimiento para recibir al panadero que le provee de pan, es por ello que no descuida de su negocio ni por un instante, ya que son muchos de sus clientes que recurren a su tienda por ser la mejor provista, ya que se puede encontrar gran variedad de productos, pero María se ha propuesto implementar ahora artículos de oficina. 
Por otro lado, su esposo trabaja en una mina, lejos de la ciudad y cuando va a visitarlo debe hacer una visita rápida para regresar lo más pronto posible a su bodega, ya que depende mucho de su negocio.

Este es su tercer crédito con MFP y se le considera una mujer muy cumplida en sus pagos, asimismo es muy responsable con la labor que realiza dentro de su banco comunal, con el cual está agradecida por haberle brindado la oportunidad de acceder a los créditos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará artículos de oficina como papeles, cuadernos, lápices y otros productos necesarios para los escolares.
texts.en:
María, 43, is married and has three children. They live in their own house. She has a store, and she feels very proud of her work. Her mother taught her about this business. She can do this work without resorting to working in the fields, which she does not like to do. She opens her establishment at 5:30 in the morning to greet the baker who provides the bread. She never neglects her business, not for a minute. There are many customers who frequent her store because it is the best stocked store. You are able to find a great variety of products there. María now plans to sell office supplies there. Her husband works in a mine far from the city. When she goes to visit him, it has to be a quick trip so that she can return as quickly as possible to her store. She is very dependent upon the business. This is her third loan with MFP. She is considered to be a very reliable woman with her payments. She is very responsible with the work she does in her communal bank. She is grateful to the communal bank for giving her the opportunity to access the loans. She will use the money she is now asking for to buy office supplies like paper, notebooks, pencils, and other necessary school supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos tiene 41 años, vive con su esposa (Victoria), de 32 años, y con sus 5 hijos: Diana de 12, Carlos de 10, Joseph de 8, Jerson de 5 e Ismael de 3 añitos, en su casa propia.

Desde hace 10 años él se dedica a brindar servicio de taxi, pues aprendió a conducir muy joven y le gusta mucho esta actividad. Es por ello que se decidió por este negocio para poder solventar los gastos de su hogar, lo que le resulta muy rentable, pues tiene buena cantidad de clientes, quienes solicitan de su servicio para poder llegar a su destino. 
Sin embargo, para Carlos su trabajo trae consigo muchos peligros, ya que ha sabido de casos que ladrones abordan los carros y terminan por robar el vehículo, felizmente hasta el momento él no ha tenido ningún percance. 
Para el  futuro, desea tener un negocio más estable como una bodega que pueda instalar en su vivieran, además de comprar su vehículo propio, pues el que tiene lo alquila.

Este es su primer crédito con MFP, por lo que promete ser muy puntual en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que solicita empezará a comprar algunos estantes para su futura tienda y así lograr que su meta sea pronto una realidad.
texts.en:
41-year old Carlos lives in his own house with his 32-year old wife Victoria and their five children: Diana (12 years old), Carlos (10), Joseph (8), Jerson (5), and Ismael (3). For ten years he has offered a taxi service; he learned to drive when he was very young and as he really enjoys driving, he decided to enter this line of work to earn money to pay for household expenses. It has turned out to be a profitable venture as he has a lot of customers who seek him out to take them to their destination. However, his line of work carries with it many dangers; there have been cases when thieves have got into cars and stolen them. Luckily, as of now, Carlos has never had an incident. In the future Carlos would like to have a more stable business like a corner store that he could run out of his home. He also wants to buy a vehicle of his own as the one he has at the moment is rented. This is his first loan with Kiva partner MFP, and he promises to be punctual with his repayments. With the money he will start buying shelving for his future store and in this way ensure that his goal soon becomes reality.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: investment in his future shop

loans.name: Patrick Musyoka

texts.en: Patrick Musyoka K. offers transport services for passengers and goods on the Makongeni-Thika route, using his bicycle. He has been in this business for three years and is constantly challenged by the bike breaking down and requiring new parts.  Accordingly, he is planning to use the loan of 20,000 KES to buy a motorbike.  His goal in life is to buy another two motorbikes and expand his business.  He is married with two daughters, 2 and 5 years old.  His dream is that his wife and daughters will all eventually have good jobs.  Patrick is honest, friendly and a dedicated father.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en:
Jumoke is 35 years old. She is a hardworking woman and a committed member of her group, and she has been borrowing from LAPO for years. She sells sarongs; she has been in business for ten years. Jumoke's focus is to expand her business and make sure customers' demands are met, thereby improving her own financial situation.

Jumoke is requesting a loan of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase sarongs to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Tania Felicitas

texts.es:
Tania es socia del Banco Comunal Emprendedora.
Tania es soltera, tiene 29 años y 2 hijos, estudios cosmetología, Tania tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, bebidas y golosinas, además Tania vende ropa a pedido.
Tania necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ropa y cerveza.
Los sueños de Tania son tener un salón de belleza y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Tania is a partner of "Banco Comunal Emprendedora. Tania is single, 29 years old, and has 2 children. She studied cosmetology. Tania owns a store at home where she sells groceries, beverages and candy as well as chothes by order.

Tania needs a loan of 1050 soles to be invested in buying clothes and beer. It is Tania's dream to own a beauty parlor and for her children to become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes and beer.

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl P. is 25 years old and engaged in the fish-selling business. Her parents are fishermen and she married a fisherman as well. She has two children and desires to give them a brighter future. Her wish is to send her children to college so that when they get older they will be able to land better employment. 

She now needs additional capital to run her fish-selling business. If ever she gets a loan at CEVI, she will buy more fish to resell to augment her sales and profit.

loans.use: To obtain fish to resell

loans.name: Jocelyne

texts.fr: Née en 1984, A. Jocelyne vit depuis 10 ans à Fidjrossè, un quartier de Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à DOUKPE Hyppolite, un employé de la SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie),  Jocelyne est mère de 2 enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Jocelyne vit seule avec ses enfants. Mais le couple se partage les dépenses familiales. Pour supporter sa famille, Jocelyne exerce comme activité principale, la vente de produits de toilette (savons de lessive et de toilette, détergents) et de manière secondaire la vente de pâtes alimentaires. Jocelyne effectue l'achat de ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Jocelyne vend ses produits non loin de son domicile. Jocelyne a été à l'école jusqu'au secondaire mais exerce son activité depuis 4 ans. Jocelyne a obtenu auprès de ALIDé 3 crédits qui ont tous été bien remboursés. Dans l'optique de renforcer son activité et de diversifier son activité, Jocelyne sollicite un quatrième concours financier auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Jocelyne was born in 1984 and has lived for the past 10 years in Fidjrosse, a neighborhood in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to Doukpe Hyppolite, an employee of Sibebra (Beninese Brewers Society). Jocelyne is the mother of two school-aged children and lives alone with her children. The couple, however, share the family living expenses. To support her family through her main business activity, Jocelyne sells toiletry items such as dish soaps, bath soaps, and detergents and as a second activity she sells basic doughs. Jocelyne buys her supplies of these products in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin and resells her products not far from her home. Jocelyne has attend secondary school and has been in this busines for four years. She has made three loans through ALIDE which have been repaid in full. With the intention of strengthening and diversifying her business, Jocelyne is requesting her fourth business loan from ALIDE.

Translated from French by David Gibbons, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy toiletry items such as dish soaps, bath soaps, detergents, etc.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy sells foodstuffs like beans, corn, tomatoes, peppers, 'gari' (cassava couscous), rice and yam flour. She buys these in large quantity and sells them retail. She is very hard-working and on days she is to stock up her shop, she leaves home as early as 5AM to be able to get goods. She has been in business for five years, and with this business she has been able to help her husband in providing for the family.

She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase foodstuffs in bulk at a better discount for resale. Mercy is 42 years old, married, and has six children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs in bulk to resell

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Circumstances have not been in N. Richard‘s favour over the last several months as he has had to endure bad yields and adverse weather conditions which have affected Nyabitete Cell, Rukungiri.

Richard is a farmer, just like his wife, and the teamwork they have together is helping them succeed. They work so hard to ensure that once they have children of their own, they will be able to take good care of them and save for their future.

Richard has been in the agriculture business for the last thirteen years and attributes his longevity in this field to his work ethic. He plans to shift to a more commercialized form of agriculture, which he believes will help him to jump out of his poverty trap.

With the loan, Richard believes he will be able buy more manure, like cow dung, and other fertilizer for better productivity.

loans.use: To buy manure and other fertilizer

loans.name: Siré

texts.fr: Siré D. est âgée de 37 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 3ans et demi et a 7 fois de suite bénéficié de crédit. Elle développe un petit commerce de miel et d'huile de palme. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et de payer la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Siré D. is 37 years old, married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the local « Banc Villageois » loan group for 3 ½ years and has already been granted seven credit loans in a row. She is developing a small retail business of honey and palm oil. Her earnings enable her to participate in the improvement of her family’s living conditions and to pay for her children’s tuition.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her commercial activity

loans.name: Tempora

texts.es: Tempora tiene 46 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Por más de 15 años, se dedica al estampado de bolsas, es así que tiene un taller en su casa, en donde su esposo e hijos la apoyan en el trabajo. Durante este tiempo, ha logrado ganar mucha clientela, como: empresas de calzados y polos, quienes solicitan estampar bolsas por millares y en el menor tiempo posible, de ese modo su negocio le es muy rentable, además ha podido ganarse prestigio entre sus clientes. Tempora está contenta con lo que hace, pese a que muchas veces tiene trasnochar para terminar con su trabajo. En adelante planea convertir su empresa en la más reconocida del mercado. Este es su quinceavo crédito con MFP, y promete ser responsable con el pago de sus cuotas, asimismo seguirá con su grupo comunal, puesto que quiere contar con nuevos aportes a futuro. El crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de materiales indispensables para el sellado de sus bolsas.
texts.en:
Tempora is 46 years old. She is a very hard-working woman who lives in her own house with her husband and their three children. For more than 15 years, she has worked printing bags. She has a workshop in her house, where her husband and children help her with her work. During this time, she has gained many customers, such as makers of shoes and polo shirts, who ask her to print bags by the thousands and in the shortest time possible. For this reason her business is very profitable. She has also been able to gain prestige among her customers. Tempora is happy with what she does, despite the fact that many times she has to stay up all night to finish her work. In the future, she plans to convert her business into the most recognized one in the market. This is her fifteenth loan with this MFP, and she promises to be responsible with her payments. She will also continue with her communal bank because she wants to be able to get new loans in the future. The credit she is asking for, she will invest in purchasing materials for printing the bags.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials for printing plastic bags

loans.name: Zenaida's Group

texts.en: Zenaida L. is from the village of Sampaguita, Solana, Cagayan. She is 57 years old and is the group leader of this twelve-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Zenaida is married and has one adult child. Zenaida owns and operates a tailoring business, providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month. In 2008, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be her fifth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Haja Balkisu

texts.en:
Haja Balkisu is a trader dealing in arts and crafts items. She has been in this business for about four years. 

She is married with four children who are all in school. In addition to her children, she has two dependents staying with her. Haja was a group leader of a united group with very good credit history. 

She is in dire need of a loan to be able to buy raw materials to produce more arts and crafts products, which will increase her profit margin. She hopes to use proceeds from the loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy raw materials

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena C. is from the village of Mabini. She is 40 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Elena owns & operates a business venture selling ocean-caught fish. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Elena  joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elena has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,500 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Elena is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP which will be used for house repair. This will be the 11th loan taken out by Elena from PMPC. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair.

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann L., 26 years old, is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Ann owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Mary Ann has been engaged in her business for over 3 years now.

Mary Ann joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Mary Ann has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Mary Ann is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the eighth loan taken out by Mary Ann from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies & equipment.

loans.name: Mariela Del Carmen

texts.es: Mariela Del Carmen tiene 27 años, esta joven se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general, Su modo de trabajo lo realiza de manera ambulante, en donde les ofrece a sus clientes la mercadería que tiene, dejándolo a crédito, y el tiempo de pago dependerá del acuerdo que tenga con cada uno de sus compradores. Este negocio le ha sido muy rentable, ya que puede aumentar sus ganancias, es por ello que desea aumentar su capital de trabajo. Por lo que este financiamiento lo realiza para la compra de perfumes, cremas, ropa interior, manteles, cortinas. Ella sueña con mejorar su vivienda para que sus hijos puedan tener un buen porvenir.
texts.en:
Mariela Del Carmen, 27, sells assorted merchandise in an itinerant manner. She offers her merchandise on credit and the repayment terms are unique to each of her customers. Her business has been quite profitable because she has been able to increase her profits. Because of this, she’s like to increase her working capital. The loan will be used to buy assorted merchandise like: perfumes, creams, underwear, tablecloths and curtains. She dreams with making home improvements so that her children may have a good future.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy assorted merchandise.

loans.name: Rosa Mercedes

texts.es:
Rosa Mercedes nació y vive en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo.  La mayoría de pobladores que viven en la ciudad de Ollantaytambo se dedican al turismo y los pobladores que viven alrededor se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería. 

Rosa desde muy niña aprendió de sus padres a sembrar, cultivar, ordeñar y pastear animales. Rosa tiene al lado de su domicilio una pequeña chacra donde siembra maíz, pasto, etc. Ya son 15 años que esta con el negocio y le va muy bien, ella vende sus productos en el mercado de Virgen Asunta de Ollantaytambo pues tiene un puesto de venta. Con su próximo préstamo, Rosa que espera recibir de $200. Le gustaría emplear el dinero de este préstamo en comprar abono. 

Rosa es una mujer emprendedora, responsable y puntual y por ese motivo sus amigas la invitaron a participar D. banco comunal “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en:
Rosa Mercedes was born in Ollantaytambo and still lives there. Most people who live in the city of Ollantaytambo work in the field of tourism, while those who live outside the city work in farming and ranching. Since she was a very small girl, Rosa learned from her parents how to plant and cultivate crops and how to milk cows and take them to pasture. Next to her home, Rosa has a small farm where she grows corn, hay, etc. She has operated this business for 15 years, and it is going very well for her. She sells her products at the Virgen Asunta market in Ollantaytambo, where she has a sales stall. With her next loan, Rosa hopes to receive $200. She would like to use the funds from this loan to buy fertilizer. Rosa is an enterprising, responsible and punctual woman, and for this reason, her friends invited her to participate in the communal bank “La Amistad de Ollantaytambo” ["The Friendship of Ollantaytambo"], of the Arariwa Association.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fertilizer

loans.name: Bertha Rosa

texts.es:
Bertha Rosa Díaz B. tiene 48 años y vive en el barrio Los Almendros de Soledad,  con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 14 y 20 años.
Tiene un negocio que consiste en  la venta de productos como ropa artículos para cocina y perfumería en general, mediante guías especializadas, que le suministra un proveedor y también adquiere a través de la compra directa en el centro de Barranquilla. Comenzó vendiendo por catálogos artículos para cocina y perfumería en general, negocio   referido por su vecina conocedora de su  capacidad como emprendedora y también porque siendo su mayor fortaleza la confección,  la inexistencia de un capital de trabajo para poner en practica este potencial, hizo que se inclinara por la venta de mercancía, teniendo en cuenta  la facilidad de trabajar con intermediarios a crédito; así fue como inició con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo hace mas de 10 años cuando viajaba a Maicao, pero suspendió y  por eso Credikiva es su   segundo financiamiento, porque necesita  con una  parte del crédito comprar una vitrina vertical para exhibir la mercancía y la otra para comprar ropa y algunos electrodomésticos menores  preparándose así para el segundo semestre del año que es una temporada donde hay repunte en las ventas. Su sueño es tener adecuado su negocio con un local y todo lo que se requiere para hacer una muy buena y agradable exhibición de sus productos de manera permanente.
texts.en:
Bertha Rosa Díaz B., 48, lives in the Los Almendros de Soledad neighborhood with her spouse and two children who are 14 and 20 years of age. Her business consists in sale of clothing, kitchen items and cosmetics via catalogue orders that she places with a distributor but she also buys direct from a market in downtown Barranquilla. She started out selling catalogue kitchen and cosmetic items, a business to which she was referred by a neighbor who recognized her enterprising capacity. Her greatest talent, however, is clothes-making but, the lack of funds to launch this potential, caused her to lean toward merchandise sales since working with middlemen on credit was a possibility. This is how she started with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo over 10 years ago when she would go to Maicao. However, she stopped doing that and now the Kiva loan is her second financing because she needs part of the funds to buy a vertical display case to exhibit her merchandise and part of it is to buy clothes and small home appliances to prepare for the second semester of the year which is when sales peak. Her dream is to have a locale that is well equipped with everything necessary for a good, permanent and attractive display of products.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Part is to buy a vertical display case to exhibit the merchandise and part to buy clothing and a few small home appliances to prepare for the second semester of the year which is when there is a peak in sales.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
